narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In the first half of the course, I learned about the formalisms of thermodynamics, including the notions of entropy and temperature and how systems evolve under different conditions. I learned about thermodynamic stability and phase transitions. The second half of the semester covered statistical mechanics, where I learned about the partition functions in the canonical and grand canonical ensemble and how you use them to derive meaningful thermodynamic statements about a collection of particles. We consider systems classically and quantum mechanically and culminate with the analysis of Fermi and Bose gases (quantum treatment of gases of identical particles).

Same as syllabus - thermodynamic quantities, Maxwell relations, Carnot's engine, identical particles, ensembles, different types of models for atoms in a solid (Einstein model, Debye model, etc), and phase transitions. This is a very nice primer for solid state physics.
Thermodynamics and statistical mechanics (stuff randing from fundamental equations to partition function)
Fundamentals of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics: Thermodynamic potentials, Maxwell relations, partition functions, boson and fermionic statistics
I learned about thermodynamics from Callen and statistical mechanics from Blundell and David Tong's notes.
Taught the fundamentals of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.
Thermodynamics, partition function, statistical ensembles,.
Basic principles of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics and how to apply them to a number of types of problems

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is very thorough and gives a complete rigorous foundation for thermodynamics. I have a good understanding of many of the concepts and calculations we did. However, I found it poorly structured, since I constantly had trouble figuring out where the current lesson fit into the larger scope of thermodynamics and how to use the results we derived. Additionally, I do not feel like this class gave me a good intuition for thermodynamics. The problem sets were generally very good with interesting problems to help with practice on the calculations, though.

The lectures were very nicely delivered and homework was the right length and covered the relevant topics that we needed to know. Straight to the point and definitely doable. However, the midterm and final did not seem to match the psets and the lectures too well. The TA for this course was incredibly helpful with the weekly study sessions.
Strength: Amazing TA who was so available and Professor Meng was a good professor too.

Strengths: Rewarding problem sets, straight-forward exams, clear content, great TA office hours.

Weaknesses: Some problem sets were unclear/modified midweek, some problem sets were far more difficult than others (and far beyond the scope of the course in my opinion).

Strength: Psets were appropriate in difficulty and aligned with the course content very well. Review sheet before the Final Exam was also very helpful. 
Weaknesses: None

This was the most horrifically poorly organized course I have ever taken. I learned nothing, understood even less, and I could not have gotten through this course without the TA holding my hand (Abhi was really great though). There was too much content that we moved through way too quickly and we were never made to understand the purpose of what we were covering in lecture. It was frustrating and traumatizing.

The strengths of this course include the notes, textbooks, take-home open-note exams, and excellent TA. The course could be improved by having a study guide/list of equations we need to know for each exam, as there were many.
It was taught very well for the range of difficulty of the course.

The course is well-organized and the lectures are very clear. The pset/exam questions were quite interesting. Sometimes it takes time to make the connection between concepts taught in class and the pset questions, but it's definitely worth the time, as you get a good understanding of how the concepts are applied to different systems at the end of the day.

Any sort of structure or organization to the material we were taught would have been helpful. Outlines of topics that we expect to cover are much more helpful than hearing "Okay, today we're talking about [topic]" out of the blue at the start of every class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The recorded lecture style was helpful, since it allowed me to review material I was confused on at a later time. However, Zoom lectures did make for a very low class engagement, since very few people tended to show up at 9:00 am late in the semester. It was often me and like 2 or 3 other people, which did not help morale in a very difficult class.
The TA was just stellar and really made the class feel more doable.
Recording the lecture was very helpful. Also labeling the recorded videos with a brief description of the content covered was very helpful.
Having the lectures recorded was really nice because you were able to go back and rewatch something if you had technical difficulties or simply needed a refresher.
The online lectures were easy enough to follow, and I appreciated both of the exams being take-home

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Don't take this class unless you're an intensive physics major.

I would recommend this class for the main reason that it is unlike anything I have ever seen before. The concepts and calculations were completely new to me. While I dont feel like I have a strong understanding of all of the concepts, I am beginning to have familiarity with some entirely new ideas. I will say, though, that statistical mechanics is extraordinarily important and powerful in its ability to connect microscopic systems with macroscopic observables. This is something I have always wondered about, and Im glad to have seen and used the mechanisms.
Top 3 physics courses I've taken at Yale.
Yes, definitely take this to expand your perspective of what physics is about. You will encounter some cool math topics along the way too.
Only if you need it for the intensive major or are interested in solid state physics. The course is without a doubt one of the hardest courses I've ever taken.

Yes, this is a great class and a nice switch up from the intensity and stress of Quantum Mechanics. PHYS 420 thrives in its clarity, content, and its ability to move from topic to topic at a good pace.
Yes; it is required for the physics major. I'd also recommend it for ambitious chemistry majors.
Avoid at all costs
This course is required for intensive physics majors, but I would definitely recommend this course to students looking for a rigorous treatment of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.
It is a prerequisite so you have to take it
Yes, lots of work but definitely worthwhile, one of the best physics courses I've taken at Yale for sure
Definitely. Very interesting and begins to give insights into advanced topics in physics
Yes if you are a Physics major.

This course is required for the intensive physics major, but I probably wouldn't recommend it to anyone not pursuing that major unless they were certain they wanted to learn about thermodynamics and statistical mechanics. It's not the kind of course you'd typically take for fun
